head.title: Rosie and Other Riveting War Heroes

hedline.hl1: Rosie and Other Riveting War Heroes

abstract.p: Ann Weissmann letter responds to Oct 22 news article about plans for a 'Rosie the Riveter' memorial honoring women who worked in defense industry during World War II; recalls discovery of the real Rosie, Rose Will Monroe, a riveter at Willow Run Aircraft Factory in Ypsilanti (Mich); drawing (M)

block.p: How good of Congress to pass a ''Rosie the Riveter'' bill that authorizes a memorial park honoring the millions of women who worked in the defense industry during World War II (news article, Oct. 22). Their pluck not only changed the course of the war but also dramatically changed the course of feminism in America.

How good of Congress to pass a ''Rosie the Riveter'' bill that authorizes a memorial park honoring the millions of women who worked in the defense industry during World War II (news article, Oct. 22). Their pluck not only changed the course of the war but also dramatically changed the course of feminism in America.

As you report, the Rosie the Riveter depicted in the original posters was a fictitious character. But a real Rosie was soon discovered. Her name was Rose Will Monroe, and she was a riveter at the Willow Run Aircraft Factory in Ypsilanti, Mich. Ms. Monroe was recruited for a film urging people to buy war bonds.

Her story was part of a recent exhibition that I curated at the New-York Historical Society. Ms. Monroe should also be remembered by those creating the Rosie the Riveter/WW2 Home Front National Historic Park.
